column1: 2014RAA....14.1578L|2014|Data processing and preliminary results of the Chang'e-3 VIS/NIR Imaging Spectrometer in-situ analysis|Liu
column20: Wei-Bin|Research in Astronomy and Astrophysics|14|12|1578-1594|The Chang'e-3 Visible and Near-infrared Imaging Spectrometer (VNIS) is one of the four payloads on the Yutu rover. After traversing the landing site during the first two lunar days
column22: and Level 2A and 2B radiance data have been released to the scientific community. The released data have been processed by dark current subtraction
column23: correction for the effect of temperature
column24: radiometric calibration and geometric calibration. We emphasize approaches for reflectance analysis and mineral identification for in-situ analysis with VNIS. Then the preliminary spectral and mineralogical results from the landing site are derived. After comparing spectral data from VNIS with data collected by the M<SUP>3</SUP> instrument and samples of mare that were returned from the Apollo program
column25: all the reflectance data have been found to have similar absorption features near 1000 nm except lunar sample 71061. In addition
column26: there is also a weak absorption feature between 1750~2400 nm on VNIS
column27: but the slopes of VNIS and M<SUP>3</SUP> reflectance at longer wavelengths are lower than data taken from samples of lunar mare. Spectral parameters such as Band Centers and Integrated Band Depth Ratios are used to analyze mineralogical features. The results show that detection points E and N205 are mixtures of high-Ca pyroxene and olivine
column28: and the composition of olivineat point N205 is higher than that at point E
column29: but the compositions of detection points S3 and N203 are mainly olivine-rich. Since there are no obvious absorption features near 1250 nm
column30: plagioclase is not directly identified at the landing site.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1674-4527/14/12/007

column1: 2010LPI....41.2168L|2010|Radiative Transfer Modeling of Lunar Soil Reflectance for Accommodating the Effects of Roughness and Temperature|Li
column4: L.|41st Annual Lunar and Planetary Science Conference||1533|2168|A Hapke's model accommodating the effect of temperature and roughness was implemented and its effectiveness was demonstrated with the data for two representative Apollo samples 15071 and 71061 from the lunar Soil Characterization Consortium dataset.|

column1: 1999nvm..conf...32K|1999|Space Weathering in the Fine Size Fractions of Lunar Soils: Soil Maturity Effects|Keller
column12: R. V.|New Views of the Moon 2: Understanding the Moon Through the Integration of Diverse Datasets|||32|The effects of space weathering on the optical properties of lunar materials have been well documented. These effects include a reddened continuum slope
column14: and attenuated absorption features in reflectance spectra of lunar soils as compared to finely comminuted rocks from the same Apollo sites. However
column15: the regolith processes that cause these effects are not well known
column16: nor is the petrographic setting of the products of these processes fully understood. A Lunar Soil Characterization Consortium has been formed with the purpose of systematically integrating chemical and mineralogical data with the optical properties of lunar soils. Understanding space-weathering effects is critical in order to fully integrate the lunar sample collection with remotely-sensed data from recent robotic missions (e.g.
column19: and Galileo) We have shown that depositional processes (condensation of impact-derived vapors
column25: etc.) are a major factor in the modification of the optical surfaces of lunar regolith materials. In mature soils
column26: it is the size and distribution of the nanophase metal in the soil grains that has the major effect on optical properties. In this report
column27: we compare and contrast the space-weathering effects in an immature and a mature soil with similar elemental compositions. For this study
column28: we analyzed <10 micron sieve fractions of two Apollo 17 soils
column31: Is/FeO = 14). Details of the sieving procedures and allocation scheme are given else where. The results of other detailed chemical
column33: and spectroscopic analyses of these soil samples are reported elsewhere. A representative sample of each soil was embedded in low-viscosity epoxy
column34: and thin sections (about 70nm thick) were obtained through ultra microtomy. The thin sections used for these analyses typically contained cross sections of up to 500 individual grains. The thin sections were studied using a JEOL 2010 transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with a thin window energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer. An individual thin section was selected from each soil
column35: and for each grain in the section we determined (1) the elemental composition by EDX; (2) whether the grain was crystalline or glassy using electron diffraction and darkfield imaging; (3) the presence or absence of rims and accreted material; and (4) the distribution of nanophase Fe where present. Most of the categories are self-evident; however
column36: we divide the agglutinate derived material into agglutinitic glass (glass with approximately the same composition as the bulk soil that contains nanophase Fe with or without vesicles) and agglutinate fragments
column37: which are composed of crystalline grains and agglutinitic glass. Lithic fragments are defined as polymineralic grains with no glass. Pyroxene grains have been divided into high- and low-Ca groups. As expected
column38: there are a number of differences in the petrography of the <10-microns fractions of 79221 and 71061 given the great difference in their respective maturities
column39: but we focus here on two major distinctions: agglutinate content and the number of grains with micropatina. Slightly over 50% of the particles in 79221 consist of agglutinitic glass and agglutinate fragments
column40: while the remainder are predominantly crystalline mineral grains. The agglutinic glass particles contain abundant nanophase Fe and vesicles. Angular particles are rare
column43: Of the mineral grains analyzed thus far
column44: over 90% of the grains have amorphous rims that contain nanophase Fe (these rims are believed to have formed by vapor deposition and irradiation effects). The nanophase Fe in these rims probably accounts for a significant fraction of the increase in Is/FeO measured in these size fractions. In addition to the rims
column45: the majority of particles also show abundant accreted material in the form of glass splashes and spherules that also contain nanophase Fe. In stark contrast
column46: the surfaces of the mineral grains in the 71061 sample are relatively prisitine
column47: as only about 14% of the mineral grains in the sample exhibited amorphous rims. Furthermore
column48: the mineral particles are more angular and show greater surface roughness than in the mature sample. Accreted material on particle surfaces is rare. Agglutinitic material is a major component of the 71061 sample; however
column49: nanophase Fe and vesicles are not as well developed as in the 79221 sample. It is now recognized that nanophase Fe is probably the main agent in modifying the optical properties of lunar soil grains. The most important result of this study is the observation that in the fine size fractions of mature soils
column50: nearly every grain has nanophase Fe within 100 run of the particle surface. (Additional Information contained in original)|
